div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: THE Doctrine of Tran≈øub≈øtantiation maintained by our Adver≈øaries of the Church of Rome, is ≈øo gro≈øs, and highly repugnant to the fir≈øt principles of rea≈øon, and univer≈øal ≈øen≈øe of mankind, that directly to defend it would be no le≈øs impo≈ø≈øible than un≈øucce≈øsful. Artifices therefore were nece≈ø≈øarily to be invented, which might palliate the deformity of ≈øo mon≈øtrous an Opinion; and divert inqui≈øitive per≈øons from a direct examination of it, by amu≈øing them with confident a≈ø≈øertions and extraneous Controver≈øies. Among the≈øe, the difference of Opinion between the fir≈øt Reformers and pre≈øent Divines of the Church of England hath of late been propo≈øed and urged with the greate≈øt vehemency; as if the fir≈øt Reformers had believed ≈øomewhat equivalent to Tran≈øub≈øtantiation; and our pre≈øent Divines, by a≈ø≈øerting no other than a figurative Pre≈øence of the material Body of Chri≈øt, had degenerated from the belief of their Forefathers.

We might ju≈øtly admire the unrea≈øonable confidence of tho≈øe men, who are not a≈øhamed to propo≈øe ≈øo manife≈øt and gro≈øs a fal≈øhood, and e≈øteem it the highe≈øt folly; if we did not remember that it is taken up to defend a de≈øperate Cau≈øe, which admits no better Remedies. Can any Man in his right wits believe that ≈øo many hundred Martyrs ≈øhould ≈øuffer death, and ≈øpend their blood for ≈øo incon≈øiderable a nicety, as was the difference between them and their Per≈øecutors in the Doctrine of the Euchari≈øt, if the≈øe late Repre≈øenters may be believed? That both Parties ≈øhould di≈øpute
≈øo earne≈øtly and vehemently again≈øt each other, and yet after all agree in the main? That the Romi≈øh Bi≈øhops ≈øhould treat the Reformers as Hereticks for denying Tran≈øub≈øtantiation; and the Reformers lay down their lives rather than acknowledge it; and yet neither the fir≈øt to have defined it to be true, nor the la≈øt believed it to be fal≈øe? Such crude Po≈øitions can find no entertainment, but in a mind already fitted to receive Tran≈øub≈øtantiation it ≈øelf, that is, devoid of Sen≈øe and Rea≈øon.

If we enquire the Rea≈øons and Arguments, wherewith our Adver≈øaries maintain ≈øuch incredible and extravagant a≈ø≈øertions, we ≈øhall find them to be no other than the≈øe, That the fir≈øt Reformers taught and a≈ø≈øerted a Real Pre≈øence of the Body and Blood of Chri≈øt in the Sacrament; That they maintained the Body and Blood to be verily and indeed taken and received by the faithful Communicants; That they frequently affirmed the natural and ≈øub≈øtantial Body of Chri≈øt, that very Body which was taken by him of the Virgin Mary, to be pre≈øent in the Sacrament. The≈øe very expre≈ø≈øions are at this day u≈øed by the Divines of the Church of England; whom yet our Adver≈øaries pretend to have departed from the belief of their Forefathers in this matter: So that if they prove the fir≈øt Reformers to have believed a material pre≈øence of Chri≈øt's Body, they will prove our Pre≈øent Divines to believe the ≈øame. For the whole Controver≈øy will come to this i≈ø≈øue, Whether they believed any material Pre≈øence of Chri≈øt's Body, or any part of it, either by conver≈øion, ≈øub≈øtitution, or union? If they po≈øitively di≈øowned this, as mo≈øt certainly they did; then what≈øoever expre≈ø≈øions they might u≈øe, they could believe no other than a figurative Pre≈øence of Chri≈øt's Body properly ≈øo called; which our Adver≈øaries now traduce under the name of Zuingliani≈øm. And, indeed, if we give them leave to explain them≈øelves, they tell us, That in ≈øuch expre≈ø≈øions
they u≈øe the terms of Real Pre≈øence, Nature and Sub≈øtance, not as Philo≈øophers, but as Divines; and that by denying the Euchari≈øt to be a figure only, or a naked figure, they mean no more, than that it is a true and real communication of the virtues and benefits of his Body, not only a meer figurative commemoration of them, which is the true notion of Zuingliani≈øm.

To prove this, and vindicate the honour of the fir≈øt Reformers and modern Divines of our Church, and demon≈øtrate the intire conformity of the belief of both; it is thought convenient to cau≈øe ≈øome one Treati≈øe of the fir≈øt Reformers concerning this Subject to be Reprinted, that ≈øo every one might judge for him≈øelf, whether the preten≈øions of our Adver≈øaries be indeed true and ju≈øt; or rather the Pre≈øent is intirely conformable to the precedent Doctrine of the Church of England. To this end, among all the Writings of the fir≈øt Reformers, this Treati≈øe of Bi≈øhop Ridley, which we here publi≈øh, will conduce mo≈øt, by rea≈øon of the great and eminent Authority of the Author, which was ≈øo highly con≈øiderable beyond that of any other Reformer, that he may ju≈øtly be e≈øteemed the Standard of the Doctrine of the Church of England at that time. Not only the a≈ø≈øurance of his great learning and eminent ≈øtation in the Church, renders this probable; but that great part which he had in managing the Affairs of the Reformation, and the extraordinary deference paid to his Authority, and tru≈øt repo≈øed in him by all Convocations, and the whole body of the Reformers, demon≈øtrate it. None can rea≈øonably be put in competition with him, except Archbi≈øhop Cranmer; and he al≈øo in his di≈øputation at Oxford profe≈ø≈øed, that he received his Opinion concerning the Euchari≈øt from Bi≈øhop Ridley. This the Romi≈øh Clergy were ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of in the time of Queen Mary, that by a plau≈øible calumny they endeavoured to per≈øuade the World, that the private opinion of
Ridley was the only foundation of the Doctrine of the Reformed Church of England: For Brooks Bi≈øhop of Gloce≈øter,
Fox's Martyrol. Vol. 3. p. 425. Queen Maries Commi≈ø≈øioner, di≈øputing again≈øt him in the publick Schools at Oxford, u≈øed this among other Arguments, What a weak and feeble ≈øtay in Religion is this, I pray you? Latimer leaneth to Cranmer, Cranmer to Ridley, and Ridley to the ≈øingularity of his own Wit: So that if you can overthrow the ≈øingularity of Ridley's Wit, then mu≈øt needs the Religion of Cranmer and Latimer fall al≈øo. To which I may add the words of Dr. Fecknam, Abbot of We≈øtmin≈øter, in his Speech in Parliament, Primo Elizabethae, made in defence of the Church of Rome, which I have ≈øeen in Manu≈øcript. Dr. Ridley, the notable≈øt learned of that Opinion in this Realm, did ≈øet forth at Paul's Cro≈øs the real pre≈øence of Chri≈øt's Body in the Sacrament, with the≈øe words, which I heard, ≈øtaying then pre≈øent; how that the Devil did believe the Sacrament of God was able to make of Stones Bread: And we Engli≈øh people, we do confe≈øs that Chri≈øt was the very Son of God, and yet will not believe that of Bread he made his very Body Fle≈øh and Blood; wherefore we are wor≈øe than the Devil: ≈øince that our Saviour by expre≈øs words did more plainly affirm the ≈øame, when at his la≈øt Supper he took Bread, and ≈øaid unto his Di≈øciples; Take ye, eat, this is my Body, which ≈øhall be given for you. And ≈øhortly after, the ≈øaid Mr. Doctor Ridley notwith≈øtanding this mo≈øt plain and open Speech at Paul's Cro≈øs, did deny the ≈øame.

Whether Fecknam hath truly repre≈øented the words of Ridley, is uncertain. But from the la≈øt words of this pa≈ø≈øage it is manife≈øt, that ≈øome, even in that time, taking occa≈øion from this Sermon, had charged Bi≈øhop Ridley with a≈ø≈øerting a Material Pre≈øence of Chri≈øt's Body in the Sacrament:
and that he con≈øtantly denied him≈øelf to have meant or intended any ≈øuch pre≈øence. In this therefore, and ≈øuch like expre≈ø≈øions, he intended only (as him≈øelf a≈ø≈øures us) to oppo≈øe tho≈øe, who ≈øo lightly e≈øteemed the Sacrament,
Ibid. vol. 3. p. 35. as to make of it but a figure. For that but maketh it a bare ≈øign, without any more profit. But to clear his intention in this matter from all remaining ≈øu≈øpicion of any kind of Material Pre≈øence, I will annex a larger explication of it in his own words, in his la≈øt examination before the Queens Commi≈ø≈øioners, September 30. 1555.

In like ≈øort, as touching the Sermon, which I made at Pauls Cro≈øs, you ≈øhall under≈øtand, that there were at Pauls, and divers other places, fixed railing Bills again≈øt the Sacrament, terming it Jack of the Box, the Sacrament of the Halter, Round Robbin, with ≈øuchlike un≈øeemly terms. For which cau≈øes, I, to rebuke the unreverend behaviour of certain evil di≈øpo≈øed per≈øons, Preached as reverendly of that Matter, as I might, declaring what e≈øtimation and reverence ought to be given to it; what danger en≈øued the mi≈ø-handling thereof; affirming in that Sacrament to be truly and verily the Body and Blood of Chri≈øt, effectually by Grace and Spirit. Which words the unlearned under≈øtanding not, ≈øuppo≈øed that I had meant of the gro≈øs and carnal being, which the Romi≈øh Decrees ≈øet forth, That a Body having life and motion, ≈øhould be indeed under the ≈øhapes of Bread and Wine.

This Treati≈øe was written by Bi≈øhop Ridley during his impri≈øonment, a little before his death, and ≈øeveral Copies of it di≈øper≈øed abroad; of which, ≈øome being carried beyond Sea, Dr. Grindall, and other Engli≈øh Exiles, conceived a great de≈øire of cau≈øing it to be tran≈ølated into Latin,
Ibid. p. 374. and Printing it. The Bi≈øhop hearing of this, de≈øired that by all means they would lay a≈øide their re≈øolution, till they
≈øhould ≈øee how God would di≈øpo≈øe of him. Accordingly it was omitted till his death. Immediately after his Martyrdom it was Tran≈ølated into elegant Latin, but in a Paraphra≈øtical way, and Printed at Geneva 1556. in 12s. The Engli≈øh Copy was Printed at London 1586. 12s. which we have now cau≈øed to be faithfully Reprinted; adding to it out of Mr. Fox's Martyrology, divers Speeches, Di≈øputations and Determinations upon the ≈øame ≈øubject, which might farther illu≈øtrate and confirm his Opinion.

La≈øtly, Becau≈øe the late Bi≈øhop of Oxford, in his la≈øt Treati≈øe, di≈øputing of the ancient Opinion of the Reformed Church of England concerning the Euchari≈øt, and as his Cau≈øe required it, maintaining the ≈øame a≈ø≈øertion with our Adver≈øaries, That ≈øome material ≈øort of Pre≈øence was then believed; doth mightily urge the Authority of the Learned Dr. Poynet, Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, at that time propo≈øed in his Diallection; and becau≈øe that Book is not in Engli≈øh, I have ≈øelected and annexed ≈øeveral pa≈ø≈øages out of it, which may demon≈øtrate what was indeed his notion of the Real Pre≈øence; That he denied all manner of Material Pre≈øence, and perfectly agreeth with Ridley in explaining the nature of it: And con≈øequently, that he is fouly either Mi≈ørepre≈øented or Mi≈øtaken by the Bi≈øhop of Oxford.
